Award.AwardTitle: Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC) 2015 Student Support

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This project supports 10-15 students for their travel to attend the 2015 Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC). ACSAC, which just celebrated its 30th year, is a top-tier academic security conference that attracts averages about 250 highly skilled security professionals and student attendees per year. ACSAC has carved a unique role as a security conference equally attended by academia, industry, and government. In addition to the technical papers, the conference program will include keynotes by distinguished speakers, tutorials, case studies, panels, a poster session, and works-in-progress talks. This project will support attendance by students, with particular attention given to those have a paper, poster, or works-in-progress submission accepted at the conference. In so doing, it will help to provide cybersecurity students with a broad perspective of the discipline.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 31st Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC) was held in Los Angeles, CA on December 7-11, 2015. ACSAC is a top-tier academic security conference whose core mission is investigating practical solutions for computer security technology. Run by the Applied Computer Security Associates (ACSA), it brings together the foremost minds in academia, industry, and government to address the most pressing problems in applied computer security, as well as discuss seminal works in information security. The conference program is comprised of two days of tutorials and workshops, and three days of keynote talks, panels, a “works-in-progress” or WIP session, a poster session, and technical paper sessions. The conference featured a special focus on Security and Privacy in the Internet of Things.

There were 300 attendees from 24 countries, with 243 attending the general conference, and 57 attending tutorials and workshops only. The technical sessions featured 47 accepted papers out of 193 submissions, giving an acceptance rate of 24.3%. The technical sessions covered a broad range of topics, including human factors, network security, apps, control flow, securing the Internet of Things, web security, mobile, embedded devices and secure subsystems, access control, passwords, applied crypto, and hardware and reverse engineering.

ACSAC attracts many students – of the 300 attendees, 71 were students. NSF and DHS funding supported registration fees and travel costs for approximately 14 students from U.S. educational institutions. NSF and DHS funding supported registration fees and travel costs for 7 recipients of Scholarships for Women Studying Information Security (SWSIS), which provides assistance to women studying for their Bachelors or Masters degrees in fields relating to information security. NSF and DHS funding also paid registration fees for 4 students participating in the pre-conference TracerFIRE training class, a forensic and incident response program developed by Sandia and Los Alamos National Laboratories. In total, NSF and DHS funding supported registration fees and/or travel costs for 25 students from 18 U.S. educational institutions. ACSA funding supported an additional 6 students from 4 foreign institutions. All other students attending the conference and/or pre-conference workshops or tutorials received discounted registration fees paid by ACSAC from general registration fees.

Of the 31 students who received NSF, DHS, and ACSA support to attend the conference, 7 were pursuing a Bachelor’s degrees, 8 were pursuing a Master’s degrees, and 16 were pursuing a Doctoral degree. Many of the supported students had an active role in the conference: 15 had accepted papers, 2 presented in the WIP session, and 3 had posters in the poster session. Fourteen of the students were women and 8 were under-represented minorities.

During the first two days of its weeklong program, ACSAC offered 6 professional development classes or tutorials. DHS funding was used to pay honorariums, registration fees, and/or travel costs for 4 instructors teaching tutorials on Security Risk Management using the Security Engineering Risk Analysis (SERA) Method, Introduction to Android Reversing, Security and Privacy Analysis for Next Generation Malware, and Understanding and Contrasting Android Malware at Runtime.

A key goal of the ACSAC 2015 Student Support was to provide opportunities for student education, as well as training and professional development. Students participating in the conference gained valuable insight into current research. A number of students shared their research with other conference participants by presenting papers, WIPs, and/or posters. Professional/academic attendees learned from the students (and each other), and made connections that could lead to future employment. The TracerFIRE training class provided student attendees a unique opportunity to learn key forensic and incident response skills, and to improve collaboration and teamwork. The invited essayist and distinguished practitioner keynote speeches gave conference attendees, including students, leading experts’ perspective on applying security to difficult technical problems. Similarly, the tutorials offered conference attendees, including students, a diverse set of classes in key topics areas, including mobile malware, secure web applications, security engineering, digital forensics, and cloud security and privacy.

The ACSAC conference is widely publicized and open to all members of the international information security community. The proceedings were published by the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) and are generally available to the public via the ACM Digital Library (see ACSAC 2015: Proceedings of the 31st Annual Computer Security Applications Conference). The proceedings were made freely available to all conference attendees electronically via the ACSAC web site.

ACSAC greatly appreciates NSF and DHS support for student participation. The conference helps feed the development of new computer and network security technologies and their application to solve address critical security, resilience, and privacy challenges in today’s information security systems. By promoting and supporting student participation and the tutorials, the conference facilitates education and interaction and helps develop and groom the next generation of security professionals.
